Therefore let us

good.
N a late issue of "The Intercollegiate,"
we see that Harvard has adopted a new
system, by which an honor man must
follow a definite line of study, SO that he
/tiny not choose all the "snap" courses in the
curriculum, in order to attain high marks.
This is, of course, a good reform measure;
but it is really only a following out, in the
case of candidates for honors, of the Hopkins system of courses. It is another instance of one of the older colleges following
our lead. Harvard copied us before, in allowing a man his A. B. degree after three
years of work. We are often not appreciated, however. Many people do not realize that we were the first University to be
formed in this country, and that the graduate departments of all the universities were
established by following the example of the

However, for our own part, we are quite
sure that the tendency to narrow our athletic
sports to two or three is most undesirable,
and even goes so far as to react unfavorably
on those few games which are fortunate
enough to survive. We do not for an instant
believe that baseball hurts lacrosse, or that
football hurts anything else; and we do think
that the only way to faster college spirit—
and Hopkins has none too much to spare—
is to have as wide a range of sports as can
possibly be justified by the material at hand,
and the wider the range the better it will be
for the college spirit.

The Dancer.
See her small and dainty feet
Twinkling to the music's time,
Forward, then a quick retreat,
Following the sparkling rhyme.
Dancing, dancing,
First advancing,
With a rythmic swing entrancing,
Watch her as her feet make music
To the music's tuneful beat;
Dancing, dancing,
First advancing,
With that rythmic swing entrancing,
Then a shy and swift retreat.

Oh, she's merry, merry, merry,
With her dainty, restless feet;
And her lips are cherry, cherry,
—Blushing cheeks are just as sweet.
Radiant eyes that vie the stars,
With their dazzling, dancing light;
And a grace which quite debars
All the praise it does incite.
Here, now there, she trips along,
Gliding swift and then more slow;
Symphony of grace and song,
All the beauty earth can know.

Oh, those eyes and dancing feet,
Oh, that form and airy grace,
Oh, that voice so clear and sweet,
Oh, that 'witching smiling face—
Dance, and dance, and ne'er cease dancing,
Dance how long, we plead for more;
Change how oft your song entrancing,
Ever is our song "Encore,"

IN THE GRADUATE DEPARTMENT.

SENIOR WEEK.

The work of Prof. Morse and Dr. Frazier
in osmotic pressure has attracted the worldwide attention of scientists. The results of
their work will be published in the "A tneriman Chemical Journal," of which - the entire
one issue will be devoted to a resurrie of
what they have accomplished.

As soon as the passing (or flunking)
shmlow of the dreaded (and often .deadly)
finals, has lifted itself from the University
precincts, everyone will breathe a sigh of relief. For weeks an atmosphere of fateful
gloom has surrounded everyone—all have
been ,grinding, boning, plugging, cramming
--whatever you choose to call it—for every
bit they are worth. It is pleasant, then,
to realize that all evil things, even finals,
have an ending, and that at last we may
throw our old hooks on the rubbish heap,
or carry them to the second-hand book dealers.
The Seniors especially, desirous of
making a striking exit from the stage of
college life, contrive to fill their time, between exams and commencement, in as agreeable and diverting a manner as possible.
hence the festivities of Senior Week.
This year, the Seniors will be entertained
at President Remsen's, and the Dean, also,
will tender them a blow-out. Then, there
will be a grand graduation banquet at tthe
lopkins Chili, and a theatre party, followed
by a smoker. Finally the Senior Prom will
wind things up in a blaze of glory.
This is certainly a delightful program,
and it is unfortunate that the lateness of
the exams will render it necessary to "concentrate" things a little. The trip down the
Ray, for instance, which is usually a most
attractive feature, will probably be omitted.
Nevertheless, the men will have a good
enough time, and when at last the moment
for receiving the degree—the last gift of the
Alma Mater—is at hand, everyone will be
sure to feel sincere regret that the happy
college days are over.

Mr. Lewis E. Jewell, of the department of
physics, will leave in duly for Africa to
assist in the observations of the solar eclipse
which will be visible there some time in
August. If on the day of the eclipse, the
sky should be clear, the 4000 mile journey
will not he in vain; but should a single cloud
intervene at the fatal moment, Mr. Jewell,
who will act as photographer for the expedition, will come home empty-handed.

Progress of the Season Ticket Plan.
When this issue shall have come from
P155 it is probable that the season athletic
ticket will have become a reality. .Personal
assurances from a large majority of the members of the executive committee of the Athletic Association lead us to believe that the
Association will itself assume the risk of the
change, iinil authorize season tickets for studelits, and probably alumni, at a greatly reduced price, admitting purchasers to Hopkins games held in Baltimore in 1905-6.
Such an action of the Association would
be a. distinct concession to the students, and
would merit universal support. The plan
'for season tickets was neither originated nor
was it fostered by the Association.. It is no
cunning plan to collect more money from
students. On the other hand, it is a measure
put forward by the students themselves with
a. view toward their own benefit. We believe
that in the end the Association will also
gain, but in the beginning it obviously assumes considerable risk. The selling-price
for tickets is calculated on the asKumption
that the whole, or nearly the whole, of the
student-body will purchase; and should any
I arge pmportion of the students fail to do
so, the income of the teams might be seriously curtailed.
We feel sure, however, that the Association will not have cause to regret its publicspirited action. The following letters from
the two undergraduate classes which will
return to the University next year make the
sentiments of the University at large plainer
than any words of ours could do. The Junior
document contains names of over 90 per cent.
of the class, while that of the Freshmen has
slightly less. We are informed that in the
latter case not all the members of the class
had the opportunity to sign. The letters
follow:—

HOPKINS-VIRGINIA DUAL MEET.
As all the world knows (or should know)
Hopkins won the dual meet with Virginia,
Saturday, May 13th, at Maryland Oval. This
makes the third consecutive victory; and
while the contest was closer than ever hefore, nevertheless Hopkins won by the comfortable margin of 12 points-58 to 46.
The track was in first class shape and fast
time was made in most of the events. Hill
did by far the best Nvork for Hopkins, taking
four first places. Lawson did the next best,
getting one first and two seconds out of the
five events in which he was entered.
Two Maryland records were broken. Hill
ran the 120 yard hurdles in 16A seconds, and
Griffith lowered the time in the mile to 4
minutes, 49 seconds. Unfortunately, Griffith's record will not count, since through a
mistake there were but two timers present,
while the rules require three.

11

The 120 yard hurdles was a beautiful race
which took two heats to decide the winner.
The first heat resulted in a tie between Hill.
.1. II. U., and Randolph, Va. In the run-oft
lill won by about one foot. The 220 yard
d:ish was closely contested, but Bass, Va.,
in:imaged to wiggle in ahead of Padgett, .j.
II. If., by the "scales of his teeth."
A snnill but enthusiastic croWd was present and every here and there a straw hat
blossomed, out as a forerunner of Spring.
There were sonic good signs of rooting, but
even the most enthusiastic leadership on the
part of Chief Rooter Griswold failed to rouse
the men to do theirbest.

THE YEAR IN TRACK.
The track-and-field ;eason of 1905 has been
a very successful one. At the beginning of
the year, we could put our hands on 6 or 8
new undergraduates, and our eyes on 4 or 5
new medical men. We never get past this
with the majority of the latter.
The first contest of the year was the Hopkins Indoor Meet, which We won by a comfortable margin. It was impossible to get
a line on the team owing to the lack of room
in which to spread itself.
Then we
journeyed to 'Washington and found the
points so scattered that our 2 firsts—in the
880 and 440—and a second in the 880 also,
won us the Georgetown Indoor Meet.
Our outdoor season opened with the Penn
Nelay races, where we found ourselves in
a higher class than ever before. We contented ourselves—of necessity—with not taking last place. Then on May 13, we rubbed
it in on Virginia for the third time straight,
after they had made more than certain of the
result by demanding the discus, along with
the shot and the hammer. The final score
was 58 to 46, though to make. it we had to
break several State records. These records
were not allowed, however, as there were
only two timers present.
On May 20, we entered the whole team
in the South Atlantic Championships, and
got second against the combined forces of
West Branch Y. M. C. A., Tome, Balto. Med.
Col., Mt. Washington, and Md. A. C., which
were all thrown in together and labelled
M. A. C. The State Records in the in
broad jump, and high hurdles were broken
by Hopkins men, but we lost the meet
through our lack of weight-men. The score
was: M. A. C., 53; II. U., 37—with the rest
nowhere in sight.
On May 26-27, we will be represented at
Franklin Field in the inter-collegiates in the
mile, 880, broad jump, and low hurdles. The
chances of placing are rather slim, however.
J. S. HILL,
Captain, 1904-'05.

RESUME OF THE LACROSSE
SEASON.
No doubt it would seem from a cursory
glance that the present season has been unsuccessful, but it must be remembered that
our squad was composed mainly of raw recruits. The only old men were Schmeisser,
Blanck, Dill, Strobhar and Meyer. All of
these had their hands full teaching the new
men, most of whom had never played lacrosse at all.
The result of the season was as follows:—
April 8—University of Pennsylvania 0,
Johns 1 lopkins 9.
April 15-1 la rvard 4, _Hopkins 3.
April ,22—Stevens 1, Hopkins 15.
April 29—T4eh1gh 3, 'Hopkins 4.
May 6—Mt. Washington 2, Hopkins 2.
May 13—Swarthmore 16, Hopkins 4.
Out of the six games Hopkins won three
games, tied one and lost two.
Hopkins total score 37; scored by its opponents, 26.
Judging from the total score, therefore,
it would seem that Hopkins is still strong,
when we come to consider that we had the
misfortune to lose one of our best men in
the Harvard game at the most critical point
of the season. However, we must also
member that our team was radically weak,
most notably at in-home.
Also we would not be hurt one bit if we
took a few points from our opponents. We
might very well change our style of play to
that which Swarthmore used against us, but
their method of training seems to be so far
superior to ours, that it would seem a good
policy to adopt at least a part of their system.
And now a word or two in regard to the
team which We hope will regain for us our
laurels in the coming season. We lose but
three men, but these three men are three of
the strongest on the team, and they are men
who have made the game a study and whose
faithful work will be greatly missed. At
present there are no candidates eminently
fitted for these positions. It remains for
the squad of next year to develop them.
But judging from the interest displayed by
the present members of the ten ti nd the
interest which is being taken in the game
in some of the preparatory institutions of
the city, we are confident that before the
squad has been in practice many weeks there

In view of these things, perhaps it is not

recognized everywhere as one of the strongest collegiate teams of the country; and is

in the rniversity. I do not wish to make
it appear I hat it is a duty for every student

many of the men who at the present time

fascinating. sports that. ever they had the
good fortune to witness.
In closing, I would like to eongratulate
the team as a whole upon their remarkable

due to Capin in Dill for his vonstant work.
also to the old players who have aidpd by

to coach Schmeisser, whose loyal and earnest efforts will never be forgotten by all
members of the team who have profited by
his teaching. "The labor of love," so generously given' by "Father Bill" will ever
be remembered.
J. EARLE MIFFLIN,

SWARTHMORE, 16; HOPKINS,4.
Just three weeks ago to-day, our good
star had reached the loftiest heights of the
heavens, and smiled down upon the lacrosse
enthusiasts with all of its radiant brilliancy,
for on the following day we were to meet
Swarthmore in the annual game_for the
intercollegiate lacrosse honors. The defense
was invincible, and the attack could not be
checked in its mad career when advancing
the ball down the field upon Swarthmore's
goal! Such were the opinions of some, and
such we all tried to persuade ourselves would
be the case.
13ut, sad to relate, when the contest began, it was seen that our star was on the
descendant, and 'our fondest hopes were

14

THE NEWS-LETTER.

soon shattered. The game was played and
won—by Swarthmore—the championship
lost, and all by the overwhelming score of
16 to 4.
This is the largest score ever rolled up
against any team wearing the Black and
Blue, and to think that it should be made
by Swarthmore, a team which, for years,
Hopkins held between the finger and thumb.
That day will always be remembered here
as a particularly sad one in Hopkins lacrosse
history, arid one which will bring pain to
true followers of the Black and Blue whenever they come to reflect upon it.
From the very first face-off, it was clearly
seen that Hopkins was up against a tough
proposition. Our players found it hard to
be in the right place at the proper time,
and verily -there was many "a slip 'twixt
ball and stick." 'Whenever the ball did
stick we found it rather hard to advance
it towards Swarthmore's goal, for one, and
sometimes three and four, of her defense
would pounce down up(m our runner, have
a "pot social" with him, get the ball, sail
it up the field, and leave him to pull himself
together and hobble back into place.
This was Swarthmore's play, and so well
did it work that she had made six goals,
before Hudgins was able to get through her
defense for our first goal.
A short time
later Hudgins duplicated his former performance, and only a few minutes before time was
called, Strobhar was able to make our third
score.
The score was now 9 to 3, and although
there wer.e some who predicted Swarthmore
could not hold the pace set in the first half,
and we would be able to make up the lost
ground, such surmises proved to be without
foundation. For in the. second half, our opponents played just as fast, if not a little
faster.
Swarthmore led off with the first goal,
and Dill followed a few minutes later wtih
Hopkins' fourth score.
It did look considerably brighter for Hopkins at this juncture, but this ray of hope was of short duration. Despite our noble efforts to score by
running part, of the defense down the field
to help the attack, we were unable to advance our score, while on the other hand,
Swarthmore made six more goals.
We all admit this was a hard game to
lose, but quite a different light is thrown on

the matter when we reflect upon the fact
that our team was composed mostly of inexperienced players. We will be stronger next season, and we all hope to see a team
strong enough to capture the lacrosse pennant, and bring it home to decorate the walls
of our Trophy Room.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Notes From All the Colleges.
After years of disaster with amateur coaching of her crews, Ilarvard has at last decided
On professiona I tuition for her oarsmen.
The freshman class of Yale, by its constitution, adopted recently, has voted to follow
the custom set by it two predeeessors, and
elect new officers each yea r. This new enstom] is considered a go)od one. Heretofore
the officers of a class have been chosen for
the whole life of the class, hardly before it
has become united, and the choice has been
made either upon grounds of athletic ability
or "prep" school popularity.
Hereafter a candidate for a degree with
distinction at Harvard, must enter a certain
group and continue one line of study. To
acquire distinction honors upon general
"snap" courses alone, therefore, will be impossible.
According to statistics compiled by. Dean
Penniman, the average of college freshmen
at Pennsylvania is increasing. The average
of the present class is nineteen years four
months and seven days, which is several
months older than that of classes of a few
years ago.
Baseball has spread to such an extent in
Japan that there is now hardly a university
in the country which is not represented by
its baseball team. The attendance at games
sometimes reaches as high as five thousand.
"Rooting" at games is hardly ever indulged
in.

The University of Pennsylvania is already
making preparations for assisting in the celebration of the Franklin bicentennial iii
Philadelphia next year.
As Benj;i in ii
Franklin was the founder of the university,
the trustees will have a special celebration
ill honor of his memory, The exercises will
be at
by all the leading officials of the
United States government, including. the
President, his Cabinet, and members of both
branches of Congress. Representatives will
also he present from England and France
and other European governments, as well as
from all the leading universities of Europe
and America.
The Cornell "Daily Sun" has lately been
incorporated, the stock being taken partly
I y editors chosen from students, partly by
Ithaca business men. The latter will remain
as permanent directors, the editorial management being handed on from class to class as
heretofore.
Incorporation, it is believed,
will give the paper greater continuity, and
put it upon a firmer business basis.

However, for our own part, we are quite

sports to two or three is most undesirable,

believe that baseball hurts lacrosse, or that
football hurts anything else; and we do think
that the only way to faster college spirit—
and Hopkins has none too much to spare—
is to have as wide a range of sports as can
possibly be justified by the material at hand,
and the wider the range the better it will be
for the college spirit.

The Dancer.
See her small and dainty feet
Twinkling to the music's time,
Forward, then a quick retreat,
Following the sparkling rhyme.
Dancing, dancing,
First advancing,
With a rythmic swing entrancing,
Watch her as her feet make music
To the music's tuneful beat;
Dancing, dancing,
First advancing,
With that rythmic swing entrancing,
Then a shy and swift retreat.

Oh, she's merry, merry, merry,
With her dainty, restless feet;
And her lips are cherry, cherry,
—Blushing cheeks are just as sweet.
Radiant eyes that vie the stars,
With their dazzling, dancing light;
And a grace which quite debars
All the praise it does incite.
Here, now there, she trips along,
Gliding swift and then more slow;
Symphony of grace and song,
All the beauty earth can know.

Oh, those eyes and dancing feet,
Oh, that form and airy grace,
Oh, that voice so clear and sweet,
Oh, that 'witching smiling face—
Dance, and dance, and ne'er cease dancing,
Dance how long, we plead for more;
Change how oft your song entrancing,
Ever is our song "Encore,"

IN THE GRADUATE DEPARTMENT.

SENIOR WEEK.

The work of Prof. Morse and Dr. Frazier
in osmotic pressure has attracted the worldwide attention of scientists. The results of
their work will be published in the "A tneriman Chemical Journal," of which - the entire
one issue will be devoted to a resurrie of
what they have accomplished.

As soon as the passing (or flunking)
shmlow of the dreaded (and often .deadly)
finals, has lifted itself from the University
precincts, everyone will breathe a sigh of relief. For weeks an atmosphere of fateful
gloom has surrounded everyone—all have
been ,grinding, boning, plugging, cramming
--whatever you choose to call it—for every
bit they are worth. It is pleasant, then,
to realize that all evil things, even finals,
have an ending, and that at last we may
throw our old hooks on the rubbish heap,
or carry them to the second-hand book dealers.
The Seniors especially, desirous of
making a striking exit from the stage of
college life, contrive to fill their time, between exams and commencement, in as agreeable and diverting a manner as possible.
hence the festivities of Senior Week.
This year, the Seniors will be entertained
at President Remsen's, and the Dean, also,
will tender them a blow-out. Then, there
will be a grand graduation banquet at tthe
lopkins Chili, and a theatre party, followed
by a smoker. Finally the Senior Prom will
wind things up in a blaze of glory.
This is certainly a delightful program,
and it is unfortunate that the lateness of
the exams will render it necessary to "concentrate" things a little. The trip down the
Ray, for instance, which is usually a most
attractive feature, will probably be omitted.
Nevertheless, the men will have a good
enough time, and when at last the moment
for receiving the degree—the last gift of the
Alma Mater—is at hand, everyone will be
sure to feel sincere regret that the happy
college days are over.

Mr. Lewis E. Jewell, of the department of
physics, will leave in duly for Africa to
assist in the observations of the solar eclipse
which will be visible there some time in
August. If on the day of the eclipse, the
sky should be clear, the 4000 mile journey
will not he in vain; but should a single cloud
intervene at the fatal moment, Mr. Jewell,
who will act as photographer for the expedition, will come home empty-handed.

Progress of the Season Ticket Plan.
When this issue shall have come from
P155 it is probable that the season athletic
ticket will have become a reality. .Personal
assurances from a large majority of the members of the executive committee of the Athletic Association lead us to believe that the
Association will itself assume the risk of the
change, iinil authorize season tickets for studelits, and probably alumni, at a greatly reduced price, admitting purchasers to Hopkins games held in Baltimore in 1905-6.
Such an action of the Association would
be a. distinct concession to the students, and
would merit universal support. The plan
'for season tickets was neither originated nor
was it fostered by the Association.. It is no
cunning plan to collect more money from
students. On the other hand, it is a measure
put forward by the students themselves with
a. view toward their own benefit. We believe
that in the end the Association will also
gain, but in the beginning it obviously assumes considerable risk. The selling-price
for tickets is calculated on the asKumption
that the whole, or nearly the whole, of the
student-body will purchase; and should any
I arge pmportion of the students fail to do
so, the income of the teams might be seriously curtailed.
We feel sure, however, that the Association will not have cause to regret its publicspirited action. The following letters from
the two undergraduate classes which will
return to the University next year make the
sentiments of the University at large plainer
than any words of ours could do. The Junior
document contains names of over 90 per cent.
of the class, while that of the Freshmen has
slightly less. We are informed that in the
latter case not all the members of the class
had the opportunity to sign. The letters
follow:—

HOPKINS-VIRGINIA DUAL MEET.
As all the world knows (or should know)
Hopkins won the dual meet with Virginia,
Saturday, May 13th, at Maryland Oval. This
makes the third consecutive victory; and
while the contest was closer than ever hefore, nevertheless Hopkins won by the comfortable margin of 12 points-58 to 46.
The track was in first class shape and fast
time was made in most of the events. Hill
did by far the best Nvork for Hopkins, taking
four first places. Lawson did the next best,
getting one first and two seconds out of the
five events in which he was entered.
Two Maryland records were broken. Hill
ran the 120 yard hurdles in 16A seconds, and
Griffith lowered the time in the mile to 4
minutes, 49 seconds. Unfortunately, Griffith's record will not count, since through a
mistake there were but two timers present,
while the rules require three.

11

The 120 yard hurdles was a beautiful race
which took two heats to decide the winner.
The first heat resulted in a tie between Hill.
.1. II. U., and Randolph, Va. In the run-oft
lill won by about one foot. The 220 yard
d:ish was closely contested, but Bass, Va.,
in:imaged to wiggle in ahead of Padgett, .j.
II. If., by the "scales of his teeth."
A snnill but enthusiastic croWd was present and every here and there a straw hat
blossomed, out as a forerunner of Spring.

THE YEAR IN TRACK.
The track-and-field ;eason of 1905 has been
a very successful one. At the beginning of
the year, we could put our hands on 6 or 8
new undergraduates, and our eyes on 4 or 5
new medical men. We never get past this
with the majority of the latter.
The first contest of the year was the Hopkins Indoor Meet, which We won by a comfortable margin. It was impossible to get
a line on the team owing to the lack of room
in which to spread itself.
Then we
journeyed to 'Washington and found the
points so scattered that our 2 firsts—in the
880 and 440—and a second in the 880 also,
won us the Georgetown Indoor Meet.
Our outdoor season opened with the Penn
Nelay races, where we found ourselves in
a higher class than ever before. We contented ourselves—of necessity—with not taking last place. Then on May 13, we rubbed
it in on Virginia for the third time straight,
after they had made more than certain of the
result by demanding the discus, along with
the shot and the hammer. The final score
was 58 to 46, though to make. it we had to
break several State records. These records
were not allowed, however, as there were
only two timers present.
On May 20, we entered the whole team
in the South Atlantic Championships, and
got second against the combined forces of
West Branch Y. M. C. A., Tome, Balto. Med.
Col., Mt. Washington, and Md. A. C., which
were all thrown in together and labelled
M. A. C. The State Records in the in
broad jump, and high hurdles were broken
by Hopkins men, but we lost the meet
through our lack of weight-men. The score
was: M. A. C., 53; II. U., 37—with the rest
nowhere in sight.
On May 26-27, we will be represented at
Franklin Field in the inter-collegiates in the
mile, 880, broad jump, and low hurdles. The
chances of placing are rather slim, however.
J. S. HILL,
Captain, 1904-'05.

RESUME OF THE LACROSSE
SEASON.
No doubt it would seem from a cursory
glance that the present season has been unsuccessful, but it must be remembered that
our squad was composed mainly of raw recruits. The only old men were Schmeisser,
Blanck, Dill, Strobhar and Meyer. All of
these had their hands full teaching the new
men, most of whom had never played lacrosse at all.
The result of the season was as follows:—
April 8—University of Pennsylvania 0,
Johns 1 lopkins 9.
April 15-1 la rvard 4, _Hopkins 3.
April ,22—Stevens 1, Hopkins 15.
April 29—T4eh1gh 3, 'Hopkins 4.
May 6—Mt. Washington 2, Hopkins 2.
May 13—Swarthmore 16, Hopkins 4.
Out of the six games Hopkins won three
games, tied one and lost two.
Hopkins total score 37; scored by its opponents, 26.
Judging from the total score, therefore,
it would seem that Hopkins is still strong,
when we come to consider that we had the
misfortune to lose one of our best men in
the Harvard game at the most critical point
of the season. However, we must also
member that our team was radically weak,
most notably at in-home.
Also we would not be hurt one bit if we
took a few points from our opponents. We
might very well change our style of play to
that which Swarthmore used against us, but
their method of training seems to be so far
superior to ours, that it would seem a good
policy to adopt at least a part of their system.
And now a word or two in regard to the
team which We hope will regain for us our
laurels in the coming season. We lose but
three men, but these three men are three of
the strongest on the team, and they are men
who have made the game a study and whose
faithful work will be greatly missed. At
present there are no candidates eminently
fitted for these positions. It remains for
the squad of next year to develop them.
But judging from the interest displayed by
the present members of the ten ti nd the
interest which is being taken in the game
in some of the preparatory institutions of
the city, we are confident that before the
squad has been in practice many weeks there

Lacrosse Team 1905.
will be strong rivalry for these positions.
!knee it seems that we have a good outlook
for a most successful smson.
In view of these things, perhaps it is not
out of place to say a word in regard to the
attendance of the students. Our team is
recognized everywhere as one of the strongest collegiate teams of the country; and is
certainly the strongest branch of athletics
in the rniversity. I do not wish to make
it appear I hat it is a duty for every student
to attend all games—they should rather consider it a pleasure—and I am sure that if
many of the men who at the present time
take no interest whatsoever in the team
would attend a few of the games, they would
begin to realize that this is one of the most
fascinating. sports that. ever they had the
good fortune to witness.
In closing, I would like to eongratulate
the team as a whole upon their remarkable
showing in the up-hill struggle, through
which they have just passed. Thanks are
due to Capin in Dill for his vonstant work.
also to the old players who have aidpd by
coaching the teant. Especial thanks are due

to coach Schmeisser, whose loyal and earnest efforts will never be forgotten by all
members of the team who have profited by
his teaching. "The labor of love," so generously given' by "Father Bill" will ever
be remembered.
J. EARLE MIFFLIN,
Manager.

SWARTHMORE, 16; HOPKINS,4.
Just three weeks ago to-day, our good
star had reached the loftiest heights of the
heavens, and smiled down upon the lacrosse
enthusiasts with all of its radiant brilliancy,
for on the following day we were to meet
Swarthmore in the annual game_for the
intercollegiate lacrosse honors. The defense
was invincible, and the attack could not be
checked in its mad career when advancing
the ball down the field upon Swarthmore's
goal! Such were the opinions of some, and
such we all tried to persuade ourselves would
be the case.
13ut, sad to relate, when the contest began, it was seen that our star was on the
descendant, and 'our fondest hopes were

14

THE NEWS-LETTER.

soon shattered. The game was played and
won—by Swarthmore—the championship
lost, and all by the overwhelming score of
16 to 4.
This is the largest score ever rolled up
against any team wearing the Black and
Blue, and to think that it should be made
by Swarthmore, a team which, for years,
Hopkins held between the finger and thumb.
That day will always be remembered here
as a particularly sad one in Hopkins lacrosse
history, arid one which will bring pain to
true followers of the Black and Blue whenever they come to reflect upon it.
From the very first face-off, it was clearly
seen that Hopkins was up against a tough
proposition. Our players found it hard to
be in the right place at the proper time,
and verily -there was many "a slip 'twixt
ball and stick." 'Whenever the ball did
stick we found it rather hard to advance
it towards Swarthmore's goal, for one, and
sometimes three and four, of her defense
would pounce down up(m our runner, have
a "pot social" with him, get the ball, sail
it up the field, and leave him to pull himself
together and hobble back into place.
This was Swarthmore's play, and so well
did it work that she had made six goals,
before Hudgins was able to get through her
defense for our first goal.
A short time
later Hudgins duplicated his former performance, and only a few minutes before time was
called, Strobhar was able to make our third
score.
The score was now 9 to 3, and although
there wer.e some who predicted Swarthmore
could not hold the pace set in the first half,
and we would be able to make up the lost
ground, such surmises proved to be without
foundation. For in the. second half, our opponents played just as fast, if not a little
faster.
Swarthmore led off with the first goal,
and Dill followed a few minutes later wtih
Hopkins' fourth score.
It did look considerably brighter for Hopkins at this juncture, but this ray of hope was of short duration. Despite our noble efforts to score by
running part, of the defense down the field
to help the attack, we were unable to advance our score, while on the other hand,
Swarthmore made six more goals.
We all admit this was a hard game to
lose, but quite a different light is thrown on

the matter when we reflect upon the fact
that our team was composed mostly of inexperienced players. We will be stronger next season, and we all hope to see a team
strong enough to capture the lacrosse pennant, and bring it home to decorate the walls
of our Trophy Room.

Notes From All the Colleges.
After years of disaster with amateur coaching of her crews, Ilarvard has at last decided
On professiona I tuition for her oarsmen.
The freshman class of Yale, by its constitution, adopted recently, has voted to follow
the custom set by it two predeeessors, and
elect new officers each yea r. This new enstom] is considered a go)od one. Heretofore
the officers of a class have been chosen for
the whole life of the class, hardly before it
has become united, and the choice has been
made either upon grounds of athletic ability
or "prep" school popularity.
Hereafter a candidate for a degree with
distinction at Harvard, must enter a certain
group and continue one line of study. To
acquire distinction honors upon general
"snap" courses alone, therefore, will be impossible.
According to statistics compiled by. Dean
Penniman, the average of college freshmen
at Pennsylvania is increasing. The average
of the present class is nineteen years four
months and seven days, which is several
months older than that of classes of a few
years ago.
Baseball has spread to such an extent in
Japan that there is now hardly a university
in the country which is not represented by
its baseball team. The attendance at games
sometimes reaches as high as five thousand.
"Rooting" at games is hardly ever indulged
in.

The University of Pennsylvania is already
making preparations for assisting in the celebration of the Franklin bicentennial iii
Philadelphia next year.
As Benj;i in ii
Franklin was the founder of the university,
the trustees will have a special celebration
ill honor of his memory, The exercises will
be at
by all the leading officials of the
United States government, including. the
President, his Cabinet, and members of both
branches of Congress. Representatives will
also he present from England and France
and other European governments, as well as
from all the leading universities of Europe
and America.
The Cornell "Daily Sun" has lately been
incorporated, the stock being taken partly
I y editors chosen from students, partly by
Ithaca business men. The latter will remain
as permanent directors, the editorial management being handed on from class to class as
heretofore.
Incorporation, it is believed,
will give the paper greater continuity, and
put it upon a firmer business basis.
